lead_paragraph: BRYANT--H. Stafford, 90, died peacefully at his home on June 27. He was the most beloved husband and closest friend of his wife Sylvie and cousin to Christine, Rob, Charlotte and Jean. Always the Virginian gentleman, his was a long and graceful life. Raised in Lynchburg, Virginia, he attended Washington & Lee University and spent the last year of World War II in the US navy. Starting out as a journalist with the Lynchburg News, he went on to the Bethlehem Globe Times, and the Savannah Evening Press before moving to New York where he spent over 25 years at WW Norton Publishers. Author of "The Georgian Locomotive" and other publications on trains, he was also co-editor with Henry Hope Reed of the "Classical America" series and served on the Board of Directors of the organization. His passion for jazz was equaled only by his profound knowledge of French and American decorative arts, his ability to evoke them in his home, and his deep love for all matters related to Virginia. 1
